REVIEW: Aug 30 2009	We enjoyed our experience and would return to the Desert Rose.	We wanted to explore Las Vegas with our two college-age children. We stayed 4 nights and the 2 bedroom-2 bath suite was perfect for our group. The rooms were nicely furnished, but not to the standard of the high-end strip hotels. WHO CARES? If you want extravagance, stay on the strip. If separate beds and baths, a kitchen and living area are more important, the Desert Rose works well. With different people going different places and keeping different hours, the 2 bed/2 bath set-up provided plenty of privacy for all. PROS: Proximity to the Strip; WIFI; good housekeeping; free parking; free continental breakfast; free beverages and snacks 5-7 pm during the week; grounds were secureSUGGESTIONS: Increase number of tables and chairs in the area adjacent to the pool;add a couple more items at the continental breakfast. With a group like ours, diverse in ages, interests and agendas, we would definitely reccommend and would return to the Desert Inn.

Aug 30 2009 	Wow what a gem	This hotel is located right behind the Hooters Casino-Hotel, about 5 minutes from the MGM. I truly loved the service, the rooms, the location. I felt like I was in my condo (kitchen full equipped (even with microwave, blender, pots and pans.. I mean anything you need is there). Front desk is really helpful and the staff is really nice. Room are nice and spacious (with 2 tvs and plenty of room). Before booking this hotel, I read all the reviews because I really need to be comfortable in a hotel room and let me tell you that I was still surprised how nice it was. By the pool you have 2 huge bbq's for your convenience if you want to cook. I've read previous previous saying that they didn't get much for breakfast ! Well, I don't know where they went because at Desert Rose, the breakfast is enough to fill you up until dinner time (cold boiled egg that I heat up in microwave, ham, bread, cereals(3 choices), bananas, muffins, coffee, tea, soda, juice, cheese, yogourt) and it's self service so you eat as much as you need. Helped me save money by just eating out once a dayPlus : Parking is free, 5@7 from Monday to Thursdays with nachos and drinks for free, there a small store at the front desk for snacks etc and it's pretty cheap, there are laundry rooms (self-service I think), nice pool with jacuzziNow the downside : There's nobody holdings doors for you when you have luggage or anything (it's really like as if you were at home), cleaning lady just changes your towels and does bed (nothing like a deep cleaning) on your stay. Honestly I didn't mind at all. I don't like cleaning lady coming everyday in my room to clean especially when it's perfect when I arrive. I also didn't mind not having clerks helping with luggage because this was the only downlfall I saw and for me that's not important.Because MGM is so big and has 2 entry (one on the Strip and the other on Tropicana), you are 5 min from MGM but 7-10 to the Strip. Well, I love walking and when in Vegas, expect to walk alot. So the 10 min to the New York New York Hotel was really nothing. It's so safe in Vegas that we never took a cab (besides for the airport) even after clubbing. There's also Deuce bus on the Strip (3$ a way or 7$ for 24h)Honestly, I'm really please to have stayed at this hotel (it was my little retreat from all the action on the strip)

Aug 26 2009 	Breakfast is no option! Probably not coming back.	During our trip to the west coast we planned to stay 4 nights in Las Vegas. The place was very crouded. breakfast is no option: small room, long lines (like an attraction in a theme park), noisy, no place to sit (to find a table is like to find a parking spot in midtown Manhattan), and if you find one - its dirty and you have to clean it yourself. poor selection in breakfast: after first morning - my kids didn't want to return. breakfast end at 9 am - not very convient, and from building 4 you have to drive!Rooms are nice and comfortable, no complaints about that, but public corridors are old, not renovated (like an old Motel 6), and open, so during hot summer days it is very unpleasant. The pool was not great either: old, and not so clean. many of the guests is like what you would find in a low grade motel.Business center - if you want to check something in the computer - the rate is "only" $4 for 15 minutes! unbelievable.Next time we probably wont come back. Aug 26 2009 	Best thing about Las Vegas!	I searched long and hard to find a room when we were booking our trip to Vegas. I see some people have commented on how dirty the carpet was but if you saw the city and with the heat and grime they would have to replace the carpet every week to prevent that. Aug 20 2009 	Enjoyable Stay	My family of six stayed at this hotel recently. We booked a 2-bedroom and a 1-bedroom suite. Aug 17 2009 	We are always happy here!	My family and I travel to Las Vegas 3 or 4 times a year. Jul 31 2009 	Everything Came Up Roses at DRR	I just stayed at Desert Rose Resort (DRR), from 27 to 30 July, and I'm happy to report that, once again, following the advice of Trip Advisor (TA) and booking accordingly paid off. I usually stay at one of the Strip hotels or South Point (see my review for that property; still my favorite hotel overall in Vegas), but when I read TA's reviews and noted its very high ranking (no. 4 when I booked last week) for DRR -- and then found a great rate on Expedia ($46/night for a prepaid booking) -- I decided to try something different. I'm glad I did. DRR lives up to the high praise from fellow TA reviewers: its location, suites, and amenities are all excellent; and if you can get anything close to the rate I paid (or close to, say, $100/night on weekends; I usually avoid Vegas on weekends, though), I highly recommend the property.I asked for -- and got -- a nice one-bedroom suite on the third floor of a building on the back side (i.e. closest to the Strip) of the property. (DRR is a garden-apartment style resort, with three-story buildings arranged in a square around the central pool and reception areas.) Checking in and parking couldn't be easier: the process took 2 minutes, and I was off with my room keys and map to park around back, right next to my building. All the gates to the buildings and main facilities are locked and accessible only with one's room key, which worked every time I used it. My suite was just fine: as promised, full kitchen, granite countertops, separate bedroom. The decor and furnishings are very similar to those at the South Point Hotel, so much so -- especially in the bathroom -- that I think DRR used the same company for its makeover. I had two TVs -- they were large CRT units, rather than the promised flatscreens, but that wasn't an issue, as I don't use TVs much in Vegas hotels. Both TVs worked and provided plenty of free channels, and it was handy having one in the living room and one in the bedroom. As some other reviewers have noted, the suites have good, strong A/C (70s/80s-style lever thermostat but works fine), but the temperature in my bedroom was always a few degrees warmer than that in the living area. No matter; I just kept the thermostat low, and the BR was sufficiently cool. I didn't partake of the free continental breakfast, but I appreciated the Starbucks coffee available throughout the day and early evening in the lobby, as well as the free beer and wine from 5 to 7 p.m. Again, a nice touch that sets the DRR apart from most other Vegas hotels.One of the best features of DRR is its location. Las Vegas, which is rarely free of traffic problems, has become particularly unfriendly to the automobile as of late, especially on the surface roads just east of the Strip. Many of the most heavily used roads, including Koval, Harmon, Flamingo, and Tropicana, are undergoing major, traffic jam-inducing reroutings and repairs. Fortunately, DRR is easy to get to, even with the upheaval taking place on Tropicana, and it's a very short drive or walk to the Strip. (The hotel is also accessible from Reno Rd., which is free of construction and leads right to the Strip.) Parking is a dream; you park right next to your building, and that's it. DRR is not very big, either, which adds to its human feel.While I'm a solo traveler, I noticed lots of families with kids at DRR, and I can see why: it's an outstanding value for families, and it really is an attractive, user-friendly property. The full kitchens, decent (though only adequate) pool, and other family-friendly facilities make DRR an excellent choice for most travelers. At night, the property is very quiet, and when in my room, I heard no noise from other guests. If you've been to Vegas before, you know what a rare treat that is. The free wireless internet, which I found to be fast and reliable, is also a great touch and one that you don't find in most Vegas hotels. Unlike some properties that give one limited free wifi in, say, their lobbies or pool areas, DRR's free wifi is available everywhere on the property, including in your suite.While I'll probably stay at one of my favorite regular hotels (S. Point or THEHotel) next time -- I do like the buzz of the bigger hotels -- I'm sure I'll stay again at DRR at some point in the future, and I highly recommend it if you're looking for a great lodging value in Las Vegas.

Jul 30 2009 	WAO!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!	Will start by saying that is the best to stay in Vegas. Desert Rose rooms are not typical hotels rooms, are small apartments. (like the big casinos) Liked the complimentary happy hour (beer, wine, soft drinks, nuts, few snacks). Staff very friendly and helpful. I would definitely stay here again.

Jul 24 2009 	Perfect for a Girls Getaway	We had a two bedroom two bathroom suite, and it was ideal for three ladies. There were two twin size beds in one room and a king size bed in the other. There was even a queen size hide-a-bed in the living room. We could have easily had up to three more ladies in this suite for a VERY, VERY reasonable price. Our suite was very clean, though a little worn (the furniture and the carpet could stand to be replaced). The bathrooms were immaculate, the beds were sooo comfy, and the sheets were so nice that we were all trying to figure out what kind they were so we could get some for our beds back home. It was great having a full kitchen and a dining table with seating for 4. There is a Wal-mart 3 - 5 miles away, but be warned - if you don't have a car it will cost you $45 round trip by taxi to go there for supplies. There was a flat screen TV in the living room and 32 inch TV's in each bedroom. There was even a balcony with two chairs on it where our one smoker was able to sit just off of the living room and smoke. She visits Vegas often, and she said this was fantastic because she usually stays at one of the casinos and has to go all the way downstairs into the casino to smoke (she prefers a non-smoking room because of her non-smoking husband). The breakfast was very good, with lots of variety. The managers reception was really nice considering that drinks were costing us $7 - $12 EACH in the clubs and bars on the strip. This place is located just off of the south end of the strip, adjacent to the airport, about a 5 - 10 minute walk to MGM, Luxor, Excaliber. Even though it is so close to the airport that I think it shares a property line, we were never bothered by planes landing or taking off. The staff were all very friendly and helpful. This is definitely the place to stay if you have a family gathering or a group of friends that want to stay together but don't want to be crowded into a standard hotel room. Really, I can't say enough good things about this place.

Jul 23 2009 	Nice place	Check in was quick and easy. The staff is very friendly and helpful. We had a 1-bedroom suite. It was very spacious. The full kitchen came in handy. Overall it was a great stay.

Jul 23 2009 	We had a great stay	We had a wonderful stay, the staff and Housekeeping were very helpful and friendly. The room we had was a 1 bedroom and it was beautiful. 1 block away from Hooters and 2 blocks from the vegas strip. We thought it was wonderful. We would definitely go back again.

Jul 22 2009 	Very comfortable and quiet	First time here but it won't be the last. Quiet, and we loved the complimentary breakfast in the AM. The only complaint was the washing machines were not working.

Jul 21 2009 	A nice spot near the strip for a family	The Desert Rose was easy to find as four tired travelers made our way in from the car rental station at the airport. Check-in was a breeze. Once we got to the suite, the kids instantly decided that they loved the room with the queen bed and the couch. My wife and I woke early the next morning and hit the limited breakfast (that was because service started a bit later on weekends). We made a trip down Tropicana to Vons in order to pick up some supplies for the rest of the week. I even had a little time after breakfast to walk down to the Strip with the two (under 10 minutes to get to the bridge between the Tropicana and Excalibur) before we had to head to the airport for our 3-day rafting trip. My wife was on her own for the next two nights, and the concierge (who was fantastic) helped her decide the best ways to hit the Strip and see some shows at night. The hotel is also very close to the airport (an easy cab ride) but we didnt hear any noise from the busy airport. One common question on the forums is whether it's safe to walk back to the hotel at night, and my wife (who doesn't like big cities) said that she never felt uncomfortable. What are some of the negatives about this hotel? The rooms will probably be a letdown for anyone that thinks they are going to a top-of-the-line resort thats just off the strip, based on the stellar rating on TA. That is not the case, and to the Desert Roses credit, they are only billed as a 3-star hotel on TA. Ive found that bathrooms say a lot about a hotel. The ones in our room left a lot to be desired, especially the one of the master bedroom, which was tiny. The resort also had a very crowded feeling at times, such as the peak times for the breakfasts/receptions, any time that the pool was in demand, or even when trying to find a parking space for the night. One other thing our teenagers commented on was the odor we were hit with when we walked down to the Strip through the Hooters lot. Thats nothing that the Desert Rose can control this, but it did make a lasting impression on our kids. Bottom line: would I stay here again? Maybe, if I were going on the same sort of trip where I needed a place for room our full family of four to stretch out for two nights, and one that was close enough to the strip that my wife could walk to some of the shows on the two nights that three of us were gone. But I'd probably pick somewhere else if walking to the strip was not a consideration, since it is very easy to drive from other parts of town to some of the casinos, if needed. And I also would suggest against the hotel for anyone who is interested in being in the hustle and bustle of some of the four or five star casino resorts in Vegas -- the Desert Rose would not fit their desires. I also think it's a bit of a stretch to call the hotel a "Resort", since it is just a quality 3-star hotel a block off the strip. I knocked my overall rating down a notch because of that, since the hotel does seem to be a bit overrated on TA. I also rounded down because of the followup email that the Shell Hospitality group sent out with a link to the TA review, since that probably contributes to overrating problem on TA.

Jul 17 2009 	An Oasis in the City	This hotel exceeded all of our expectations. The beds were extremely comfortable and the apartments were quite luxurious, spacious, and well-furnished. Coffee was provided in the room each day (Starbucks) and toiletries were always replenished. We had read complaints about the breakfast, so were pleasantly surprised by the abundance of food offered. There were bagels, packaged danish and muffins, bread, cheese, turkey or ham, boiled eggs, and fruit along with gourmet coffee, sodas, and juices. There were always lots of people there and no seats were available, so we always took the food back to the apartment and prepared it there. I was amazed that the staff was able to replenish the food so quickly, as people were taking it as fast as it could be put out. The hotel offers a happy hour for two hours each day (5-7), with complimentary wine, beer, sodas, and snacks. The pool was refreshing, but very busy during the weekend. The spa was nice and hot. There were plenty of chairs around the pool. The location was excellent....two blocks from Luxor and MGM. We had a car and usually drove to a hotel / casino and used the valet to park there ($3 tip). It was so hot that this worked out great (though the valet lots were sometimes full, in which case we self-parked in the lot). However, it is an easy walk from the hotel to Luxor, MGM, and Hooters from the hotel (10-15 minutes). I highly recommend this wonderful hotel. It was our home away from home for four nights and we would definitely stay here again if we return to Vegas.

Jun 16 2009 	We stayed at the Desert Rose for 5 nights	We stayed at the Desert Rose for 5 nights. The rooms are big: separate living room with sofa, TV, kitchen table, kitchen with everything you need (microwave, oven, cooktop, toaster, blender, coffee maker, large refridgerator and all the silverware and china you need), bedroom with another TV, bathroom with separate bathtub and toilet. The AC is noisy when it comes on but it is located in the living room and does not make as much noise in the bedroom. The staff is very friendly, hard-working, and they are trying their best during the busy breakfast time. Breakfast includes bread, bagels, packaged pastries, fresh fruit, yogurt, cereals, cold cuts, boiled eggs, oatmeal, juices, milk, coffee and tea. Breakfast is very crowded. One suggestion would be to expand breakfast hours until 10 am for the late night gamblers and to ease the congestion in the morning. One negative point, the birds have learned about breakfast too and sitting outside means watching your food very carefully.On weekdays evening there is a reception with free wine and beer, various snacks like chips and salsa and something warm, like eggrolls, tacos, etc. In the lobby area there is always free Starbucks coffee.The staff is very friendly, the rooms and grounds are clean, all non-smoking, the area feels secure and quiet. WIreless internet worked great, fast and reliable. There is a small fitness center which is sufficiently equipped. The pool area has a BBQ for grilling your own food. May 29 2009 	An oasis in Vegas--excellent!	We stayed at the Desert Rose during Memorial Day weekend. All of Vegas was packed with people, so we were happy to have found a great deal on the price. When we go there we were told that we were upgraded to a 2 BR suite for no extra charge! (we had reserved a 1 BR) That was great news because we had some friends joining us for one night & now they didn't have to stay on the pull out! The room was incredible. It was facing the pool which allowed us to check how crowded it was before we went down there. The sitting area was large & spacious, there was a separate area for dining, a large kitchenette and both rooms had their own bathrooms. We were very excited to have found this place.  The other great news: free breakfast. Not only was their breakfast free, it was quite a lot of food: boiled eggs, ham/turkey cold cuts, breads, fruit, cereal, oatmeal, coffee, juice, and more. It does get pretty crowed, so we went early & carried some back to our room. We also saved some in our fridge to make sandwiches later. It was a great deal.  I suppose one of our favorite things about the Desert Rose was that it was quiet and had no gambling. After walking through all the smokey, loud casinos all day with tons of people it was so relaxing to return to a place that was removed from all of that commotion. That's why we call it the oasis of Vegas. If you like staying amidst all the commotion, this may not be the place for you, but it is very close to MGM grand--an easy 5 or 10 minute walk--so you can get all the glitz and return to the stress-free Desert Rose. Also, from what my friends at the MGM told us, they had to wait about 30 minutes to check in & check out and using the elevators was always a chore. They had to go to the top floor just to get on an elevator to go down! We never had any trouble with the crowds or getting what we needed from the staff.  We had great service from the concierge, front desk and all the staff. I would definitely recommend this to people with kids or anyone who likes to relax while on vacation. A true find!

May 26 2009 	What a find!	I am so glad I found this place! Thanks, TripAdvisor. We spent a week hiking in Zion and decided to spend 2 nights at the end of the trip in Vegas. My husband had never been to Vegas and wanted to explore the strip but I knew the big glitzy hotels were not for us. The Desert Rose Resort was perfect! I know a lot of people complained about the walking but I don't know how you can see Vegas without a lot of walking. To go into the Venetian and walk up and down the "Grand Canal" takes longer than it does to walk from the Desert Rose to the MGM. We had to return our rental car at the airport and didn't want to deal with our luggage so we arrived at the Desert Rose at 11:30am. Our room wasn't ready but they happily stored our luggage. We measured the distance to the car rental return (3.3 miles) and decided to walk back. (I told you we were hikers!) By the time we got back (after a stop at Mandalay Bay), the Desert Rose had called our cell phone to let us know that a room was ready. Great service!Our two room suite was spotless, tastefully decorated, and very comfortable. There is a manager's reception during the week with beer, wine, soft drinks and snacks. The "continental plus" breakfast is decent and includes hard boiled eggs, which made me happy. There is Starbucks coffee available in the lobby 24 hours, I guess to keep you awake if you are out late gambling. :-)My only complaint is that the pool seemed very crowded but it was hot and all of the pools at the big hotels were crowded too. I don't think you can avoid that in Vegas in May. It was so nice to come back to the quiet of the Desert Rose after spending a day on the noisey, busy strip. We couldn't believe how long the lines were at check-in at some of the big hotels on the strip and how people had to walk through the casino with their luggage to find their rooms! No thank you! Give me the nice, personable Desert Rose any day.We plan to go hiking in Utah again and will probably fly in and out of Vegas again. When we do, we will definitely stay at the Desert Rose Resort.

I have a family of 5 and this would have been perfect for my wife and 3 kids last time we visited. Seems family friendly and certainly safe location. Room was well equipped, beds were comfortable and everything seemed new.

May 23 2009 	A very nice place to stay.	My husband and two children (ages 19 & 21) and I stayed at this resort for 2 nights. I purchased the rooms from expedia for about $100 a night. It was worth it. It was clean. Nice rooms, actually we had two bedrooms, two baths, small living room/dining room and small kitchen. It suited our needs well. We could go to Walmart about 2 miles away and get food to eat in. To get to Walmart go out to Tropicana Blvd and make a right then go about 2 miles. The only negative thing was our room was right beside a locked gate and people were coming and going at all hours. The gate was noisy when it shut. I was glad that they had them though. You need your room key to open the gate. It was nice...it was clean....liked the kitchen... it had basic needs. The pull out couch was not comfortable but that was to be expected. Also, I read on here about the blocks out there being to long or big and they were right. Expect to do alot of walking.

May 23 2009 	great place especially for family	My brothers and sister and I stayed here for 4 days and it was great-I would like to find more places like this in California and Hawaii,etc. Selma Gonzales

May 23 2009 	For wildlife lovers everywhere - if you like brown decor and noise.	I am actually staying at the Desert Rose at the moment, have been here for 6 nights as I am unable to shorten my stay without being charged for the full week.Not enjoying it one little bit so it's difficult to know where to start with my comments. Firstly I would like to warn anyone staying here of the telephone charges. I made three calls to the UK on the room phone for 3 mins 20 seconds, 3 mins 59 seconds and 4 mins 35 seconds - the charges for these calls were $53, $46 and $53 respectively. Obviously I'd expect a call from a hotel phone to be something like $10 for a few minutes but that is ridiculous. When I complained to the manager they simply had no explanation but agreed that their charges are 'extortionate'. Thanks guys.Secondly, the place is infested with moths. To a massive extent. I have just killed three of these in the last hour and they have plagued the week I have spent here. I have had them crawling on me, flapping in my ear while I was asleep, everywhere. Disgusting.Thirdly, there is a roach problem, although I have only caught 2 or 3 in my actual room, the corridors and outdoors are really bad and other guests have complained about their rooms being worse. And they're big ones too.Fourthly, although the place looks close to the big hotels when you look on a map or Google Earth, the walk is really terrible - the sewers in this block smell absolutely disgusting - to the extent that I wretched repeatedly, and there is no proper lighting. My girlfriend was approached in a car during the late afternoon and since there is virtually no one around the area and it backs onto the testosterone-fueled-moronic-whoop-fest which is Hooters Hotel it was a worry.Fifthly, forget about the pool. There are 144 large condos in this development. with I suppose an average of 3 people staying in each. There are approx 35 sunbeds. You do the maths, but even in Vegas people do like to use the pool and this one is woefully inadequate. It's not that great either. For the last four days we have been walking the mile or so to the Luxor to pay $10 to use their pool - didn't expect to have to do that but there is literally no choice.Sixthly, it's the noisiest place I've stayed since I last went to Ibiza aged 18.I didn't come to Vegas for the peace and quiet but when I put the do-not-disturb sign on the door (that incidentally says "Shhhh... I'm sleeping") I don't really expect housekeeping to slam their trolleys relentlessly against the walls and constantly SHOUT at each other. That was really bad. Other guests were loud idiots too, but I'm not blaming that on the hotel (oh, okay, go on then I will).Finally, far be it for me to be a snob but the clientele that this place attracts are very hit and miss. The breakfast buffet is like feeding time at the zoo. I't's held right in the middle of the lobby, the food is shocking and in order to reduce costs (I guess) the management provide nowhere to eat properly, no trays and flimsy plastic plates. I saw someone with a bowl of bran flakes with a hard boiled egg balanced in the middle while they poured milk on them. Another elderly lady was perched on an easy chair in her nightdress, she had clearly walked directly from bed to the buffet bypassing every sink, hairbrush and item of everyday clothing. A pink nightie with no underwear, shoes or socks was just the ticket for her mealtime - and just the thing to put me off eating. I only went to the buffet once although I did get some jam on my clothes when I sat down in the lobby another day (does that count?).I'm a well travelled chap and I'm very reasonable and give credit where it's due. The hotel was good about calling taxis to get us from A to B. The concierge booked a nice restaurant for my birthday and generally the place is spacious. The staff were on the whole functional but not particularly friendly or exceptional.I'm quite reluctant to say this is a bad hotel, because I did a lot of homework before I booked this trip and virtually everywhere I looked said this place was great. But in all honestly it's not. It's pretty damn bad. And I hate to admit I picked the wrong place but I did.But please don't stay here unless you get a knock-out cheap rate. There are way better places to stay in Vegas and some hotels have real bargain rates at the moment. If you do stay here don't make any phone calls, don't expect to use the pool, enjoy your breakfast, have any peace and quiet or a pleasant stroll to the strip. And bring a nose clip unless you like the smell of sewage. Oh, and ear plugs to drown out the noise of the outdated air-con.Do bring a microscope because the bugs and crawlies could make excellent study projects for the kids.

May 22 2009 	Hey I'm not easy to impress. This was a wonderful place to stay!	My daughter and I stayed 05/17 thru 05/21 of '09. Total for 4 nights (plus tax) was $533.96. Hey, I'm not easy to impress and am the first to complain if something isn't just right. But, for our time there at least, I have to say this was a wonderful place to stay. Maybe I didn't get a bargain basement price but I've paid a lot more for a lot less at other places. The top 10 reasons for staying at the Desert Rose ... or ... What we got for the money:1) A very clean 2 bedrooms, 2 baths, kitchen, dining area, living room and balcony. (Kitchen has fridge, microwave, dishes, utensils, blender, coffee pot, toaster, etc). The bed was possibly the most comfortable hotel bed I've ever slept in. They even provided pillows of different sizes and fill just so you'd have a choice of what you'd like best to sleep with. I've never seen anyone else do that.  2) The baths had the deepest tubs I'd ever seen in a hotel. The shower had instant (and I mean INSTANT) hot water. I don't even get that at home!3) There were TV's in the living room and in each bedroom.4) The air conditioning was wonderful and there was no AC or 'hotel smell' (i.e. people or chemicals). The air was very clean. 4) Pool (we were too busy to ever use but saw others did and never heard a complaint)5) Very friendly and helpful staff. The only time I was ever 'bothered' was when the cleaning staff actually called on the phone once to ask if I was sure I didn't want the room cleaned even though I had posted a 'do not disturb' sign on the door so I could grab a nap. I wondered then if they would have ignored the posted note if I hadn't answered the phone. Hmmmm. 6) Continental breakfast (served until 9 AM) that was more than adequate (cereal, bagels, hard boiled eggs, deli ham, fruit, etc.) No, not the very best I've ever had but close and still nicer than what most places term a 'Continental breakfast' . Besides, do you really want to 'load up' or weigh yourself down before hitting the Vegas strip? Even if you have a car or are just going to use the monorail, there is still a lot of walking around involved with your seeing Vegas. 7) There was some sort of free drinks (cocktails?) and snacks thing in the afternoon (A Complimentary Manager's Reception was the official name) that we never attended but thought you should know about. 8) Free Wi-Fi. We never used it but mention it here anyway. 9) We never had a problem with noise at the hotel even though our room was one story above the parking lot. I never heard the people in the hall or in the rooms next to us - no voices, no footsteps, nothing.10) There is no gambling at the Desert Rose. Whew! Returning 'home' to the hotel each night after being inundated with the noises of machines and people, I really appreciated there not being a hint of it waiting for me when I was ready to rest up for the next day.Final note: I'm not a world traveler but have stayed in a lot of nice hotels the last half century. Some of them thought a lot better of themselves than I did. This one, though, was a real find. The hotel claims "...this three-story, all-suites hotel is just one block from the Las Vegas Strip, yet miles away in ambience". That statement of what to expect is spot on. I regret not taking photos of the rooms to share. I meant to as the one's supplied by the hotel don't do it justice - don't even come close.Also, if you are staying in Vegas for a few days without a car, consider getting a multi-day pass for the monorail (around $25). We had 102 and 103 degree days during our stay, the monorail helped avoid a lot of walking in the heat (and I don't care who starts in about it being a 'dry heat'. A hair dryer is a dry heat. It doesn't help when you turn the setting on high and stick it in your face. It is still HOT, people!

May 21 2009 	REALLY GREAT VALUE FOR THE MONEY!!!!	We Stayed AT The Desert Rose Resort For my husbans 40TH birthday. It was amazing, the staff was very helpful. The rooms were beyond anything we expected based on the price. We are planning another trip and we willstayiing at another DESERT ROSE RESORT. Cannot say enough about this place.! It is also wthin walking distance from the vagas strip and mintues from the airport. Perfect spot!

May 21 2009 	Best Place for Families	We've just returned from staying at the Desert Rose - May 13 - 19/09. We were travelling to Las Vegas for a wedding. Got a great rate by booking directly with the resort - $100/night for the large 2 bedroom suite.We travelled with 4 teenagers and stayed in a 2 bedroom with pull out sofa in Building 4. Size of the suite was fantastic and more than enough room for the 6 of us. Large master bedroom with full ensuite was great and having a well stocked kitchen helped keep our food costs down.After walking through many of the casinos on the strip, I was very happy to be staying at the Desert Rose. I can't imagine staying in one of the large hotels and having to trek your belongings 20 minutes to find your room.The pool was very nice and a good size. My husband had breakfast and his coffee poolside every morning and found it very relaxing. The teenagers loved jumping into the water after a long day of walking in the sun. And yes the pool is not heated, but being Canadian we didn't mind! A cool pool after walking in 37C temperatures is nice.Staff were ever helpful. The only complaint we had was every week day morning we could hear the either a delivery truck or garbage truck backing up. The beeping was very annoying. Other than that we had a very enjoyable time and would definite stay here again.

May 21 2009 	Spacious and convenient great for longer stays	We chose this hotel rather than a Casino resort as it offered a 1 one bedroom suite and more space for 3 at a good price. 1 friend cancelled, so we were 2 women to the suite which turned out even better spacewise. It gave us more room for the large amount of clothing/shoes we brought. Also, the bathroom is rather small and off the Master bedroom, so people sleeping in the living room will have to walk through the bedroom. Luckily, sink and mirror are separate from the shower/toilet. Kitchen is really nicely equipped but the free (cold) breakfast was sufficient for us in the morning. It is nice to have a fridge to store leftovers and drinks, etc. The Pool area is clean and rather large but on most days there were not enough chairs and towels for all guests. The cocktail reception at 5pm is nice and filled us up until we got out for the night. The fitness room is smallish but has nice equipment. All staff is very helpful at all times. Generous parking for guests available if you rent a car (recommended if you want to go back to the hotel during the day to change or relax before nightlife, as commuting takes up a lot of time and its hot out there!). Walking distance to the Luxor is 8 minutes. From there you can catch a train (5 USD/trip). From the hotel, taxi cab to the airport is approx. 10 USD, so for 2 it is cheaper than the shuttle bus which has to be reserved 24 hours in advance. Supermarkets are approx. 2 miles away from the hotel in each direction - the nicer option here is a nicely designed strip mall (Town Square) with Whole Foods, upscale shopping and some good clubs/restaurants (Claim Jumper). Desert Rose is a nice, quite place if you dont need to be in the middle of constant party and action. Really good choice for longer stays. The guests are a mixed crowd, all ages, also some kids. The free WIFI in the room is also a nice bonus and allows to catch some good ticket deals for shows or other things do do in Las Vegas.

May 21 2009 	Gave all that was promised.	First time to Vegas so had no expectations butt WOW!!!!!!! The Desert Rose was everything it had prmised it would be.Rooms enourmous, fully equipped for all your possible needs including spare bedding and towels. Breakfast was a bit caotic but items replaced as soon as they run out.Really good location and once you learn how to get into the MGM acroos from Hooters car park it does not take long to hit the other hotels on the strip.Execellent value for money compared to the bigger hotels. Didn't really attend many of the managers free drinks as usually not around at these times (free drinks and snacks Monday -Friday 5pm-7pm) but it would have been nice to have a bar within the hotel for a quiet drink before bed, but a short car journey down Tropicana ave takes you to Vans supermarket where we discovered some lovely Califorian wines to drink in our room.Would definaltly stay again and recommend it to anyone looking to stay in Vegas
May 18 2009 	Great place to stay a few days!	This was a really nice place to stay, just off the strip, with family.

May 18 2009 	Desert it at all costs!	We booked into the Desert Rose for 4 nights from 18 April 2009 based on its reviews, proximity to the strip, kitchen and price. We were advised upon arrival at 9.40pm (I had emailed twice in advance advising of this) that the hotel had had a major plumbing problem that morning and many rooms were out of service and we would have to go to the Bluegreen resort just around the corner for the night. Interestingly we phoned from LA airport at 6.30pm just before our flight to check someone would be there when we arrived and no one mentioned anything then. Suspecting a rat, but too tired to keep arguing (following a 21 hour flight the day before from our home with a 7 and 9 year old in tow), we hopped in the taxi paid for by the hotel and off it drove and drove and drove. When we asked where we were going the taxi driver (bless this gorgeous man) pointed to some far away lights and indicated that the hotel was about half an hour walk from the strip past a huge and dangerous vacant lot. So he took us back to the Desert Rose. We said we were happy to shift to another hotel but it had to be equal or better (ie with 2 young children strip proximity was paramount). Nup, they couldnt do it. Their denial of my request to see the rooms with the plumbing problems confirmed what I suspected. After an hour of arguing - they picked the wrong jetlagged woman on the wrong night and I was ready to set up the lobby as our hotel room and put the kids to sleep on the couches  abracadabra there was suddenly a room available. Amazing. So when they try this low life trick on you I hope this story helps. Obviously we looked like total suckers  ie we paid a non-refundable rate in advance and being a busy weekend could there have been better offers on the table? We even handed back the $40 Hooters voucher we were given as I just felt sick looking at it.My advice to the hotel  lift your game in the choice of front desk managers  I doubt that the guy working on the night of the 18 April was what any hotel would want representing them. You can do far better than this. The room was nice, but we didnt use the kitchen as we couldnt figure out where a grocery store was (we didnt have a car) and didnt want to go near the front desk to ask during our stay. Vegas was great and the West Rim was fabulous.

May 17 2009 	The best time ever!!	If you have a choice, stay at this hotel! The breakfast is fanatasic, the cocktail reception is wonderful, the staff is friendly!!! Hardly spent money on food - just snacks and dinner. Easy access to and from the hotel from the airport - Airport shuttle is only $6 each way (buy both tokens at once - makes it much easier) It's a block away from the strip - MGM is across the street so there's easy access to the monorail. I'm not much of a gambler, so not having a casino at the hotel worked out great from me. You dont have to worry about smelling like smoke all the time and the noise levels are low. The 1-bedroom suite I had was spacious and clean! The private balcony was great too! Full size kitchen with appliances (blender, toaster, full-size microwave, frig & stove). A nice dinner table and chaise lounge. The bed was comfortable and big. The bathroom is a little small, but makes up for it by having a deep tub. I have been telling everyone since I've been back - this is the place to stay! I will never stay at a casino hotel again. The rooms are much cheaper for a better quality room! I have no complaints at all when it comes to the Desert Rose Resort

May 16 2009	Quiet relaxing place to stay close to strip	My boyfriend and I recently spent a week here. I recommend booking through them directly, as you might get a good deal (I checked other travel sites and felt booking through them was best and ended up paying almost half price for my room thanks to a special). There is a pool, free continental breakfast, free WiFi and Mon-Fri they have a little get together for guests and invite people to come down for drinks and snacks. I found employees to be helpful, although to help find the place quicker, it's good to note that this place is directly behind Hooters on a side street.We had a one bedroom with a fully equipped kitchen. How equipped? Go to a store nearby, buy some food and you can make meals right in your room. There's a dining area and living room area. The bedroom was nice with a big comfy bed, and the bathroom was nice too. Everything was wellstocked, clean and it made us feel like we were at home. I would stay here again in a heartbeat next time we take a trip to Las Vegas.And if you feel like gambling, shopping, eating out, clubbing, etc, you may not be able to do it here but you're close enough to the strip that you only need to go about 5 min to get to all the big casino resorts.

May 15 2009 	An oasis amongst the madness of Vegas	If you want to stay close to the Vegas Strip but also want a sanctuary away from the noise and madness of the big casino hotels, the Desert Rose is a real find. Just one block away from New York New York it's quiet and peaceful, has large, very clean apartment style suites and a pleasant outdoor swimming pool and fitness room. Friendly staff too. And very god value for money. No restaurant (rooms have kitchens) but continental breakfast included. Highly recommended.
May 15 2009 	Truly a rose ----in a Sea of cactus	A place we have no problem recommending to our friends. All of are needs and desires were meet with a friendly staff waiting to please.

May 15 2009 	Rose in the Desert	We just retuned from a week long trip to Las Vegas and stayed at the Desert Rose. We are owners of SVC in Barie, Canada, therefore exchnaged our week.Arrived late at night 11:30pm, but in our rooms by 11:45pm. Complimentary Bfast, Internet, happy hour in the evening are pleasant surprises. Room matched most of the SVC properties we stayed, well appointed. We did not have any problems staying at this resort. Will stay here if we go again to Las Vegas.Perfect location so close to the strip yet you could have your own peace and quiet if you choose.

May 15 2009 	Great spot away from the glitz	We had a lovely time at the Desert Rose Resort in Vegas. It was fabulous for a family with youngish children, like us. It was clean, rooms nice but no wow factor, handy to the Strip and main attractions, had a lovely pool, good breakfast and nibbles at night and staff helpful (except concierge - she gave us poor information more than once). Would recommend this as a great place for families who want to experience Vegas without being amongst the glitz and hype.

May 13 2009 	Good value for the money	Ceck-in, Check-out, services are fast and prompt. Continental breakfast, manager's snacks in the evening, room service, cleanliness of the property and pool side are excellent. Apartment is with fully equiped kitchen. Laundry services are cheap and good.Though the facility is just off the 'Strip' it has all the convenience of staying on the 'Strip'. However the atmosphere is serene and pleasant.

May 13 2009 	Great resort wonderful experience	Accommodations are very nice, their complimentary breakfast and cockail hour are first class. Their complimentary internet access is an unusual treat as well. Location is great, within walking distance of the Strip.

May 12 2009 	Quiet nice cheap friendly people centrally located. What more do you want!	We didn't expect much from this hotel, since we stayed in the Venetian at the start of our vacation. But everything exceeded our expectations: rooms were HUGE, you had your own kitchen, everything was nice and clean, everybody friendly, breakfast complementary, nice pool, very quiet and just off the strip. It was a pity we only had one night here before flying back home!

May 12 2009 	Great Value	We picked the Desert Rose after reading the reviews on Trip Advisor and we weren't disappointed. The staff were friendly; the rooms were very clean, well equipped and had plenty of space; the location was ideal - just a couple of minutes walk from the strip; and it was excellent value for money. We didn't feel that we missed out by not being in a gambling hotel - in fact it was nice to come back to the peace and quiet. I would definitely go back again!

May 11 2009 	Good value just off the strip with a kitchen.	Got the room on the day of my stay from a travel site. I did not know what I was getting. I was pleased by everything, from check in on. Great space, just off the strip. Instead of a little room which screams "go gamble" they offer a comfortable space with a kitchen and living room you can be comfortable in. Good value too. I'll use them again.

May 10 2009 	Excellent service and stay	Room allocated spotlessly clean but we were put next to a carpark access gate which slammed constantly when guests arrived back at resort.A quick call to the front desk and we were relocated within 15 minutes.Decent breakfast, large 2 bedroom unit clean and well serviced by staff.Tip - ask for room on top floor to avoid noise from occupants above.
May 10 2009 	Quiet and Comfortable	Exactly what I wanted - something peaceful slightly off the strip. The rooms are really nice and it was priced reasonably.

May 10 2009 	Excellent value and a quiet oasis not far off the Strip.	After reading the reviews we tried the Desert Rose and were not disappointed. Excellent value, very courteous and plentiful staff, and very quiet. If you want to be close to the action, this is not the place, but you are within walking distance of the 4 corners of the Strip. To avoid the crowds at breakfast, go early (6am weekdays, 7am weekends). No complaints, nice pool, generous poolside chairs/tables, etc, more than adequate continental breakfast, Starbuck's coffee, nice excercise room, very nice one bedroom condo, well equipped, in-room wireless internet, and all for <$50 per night (using a travel site w/discount code). Very pleased and will go back. Thank you Desert Rose.

May 9 2009 	Best room off the strip	The Desert Rose is a nice hotel w/ all the amenities of home. There is a full service kitchen which is so nice to have! The prices of the food at the restaurants are outrageous I would rather go to the grocery store & cook my own meals. The rooms were comfortable & spacious. I didn't need anything as it was all there for me. We had a nice balcony which is great for friends who smoke. The Desert Rose is in walking distance from a Casino & groceries tucked away behind Hooters it's nice, no need to pay for parking. Quiet & relaxing!

May 9 2009 	Even more than I expected	I found this hotel using Tripadvisor, and am usually satisfied - although sometimes the "best value" isn't the same as "best". In this case we found both. We booked a 2 bedroom suite (these are timeshare condo's, actually) because there were no one bedrooms available on the nights we wanted. No matter - only $108/night didn't break the bank. After travelling for several weeks in Holiday Inns, Hiltons, etc we expected a nice but standard box. However this was indeed a complete 2 bedroom apartment, each bedroom ensuite, a full kitchen with utensils, wine glasses etc. Our unit must have been upgraded in the last couple of years so everything was modern and worked well. Other reviews indicate some plumbing problems so perhaps our unit was special - the 5 nozzle massage shower was really nice, for example. Also, the three TV's seemed a bit much, but it didn't stop there. The breakfast was reasonable but not extravagant. However the free wine and cheese (and a veggie platter) at 5pm was certainly an unexpected perk. It was really nice to have a chance to socialize around the pool in the central courtyard with other guests. Furthermore, my misgivings about security of our vehicle were allayed by the rather obvious 24 hour security guard in the lot. The Vegas strip is about a block and a half away, and the airport closer still. One would expect a lot of noise, but somehow the whole resort seems to be very quiet - as if its floating in its own bubble of silence. The friendly desk staff and concierge were very good at answering all our questions. If I go back to Vegas I would certainly recommend this resort to a friend - but there was so much space in that suite that my wife and I rattled around. I imagine it would be completely adequate for up to 4 people without any element of crowding.

May 9 2009 	Desert Rose with Thomas Cook	Travelled direct from Manchester with Thomas Cook in economy, dreadful outgoing flight people crossing the aisle in extra leg room seats in row 9 even after being asked not to on four occassions by cabin crew. Gave up in the end but changed seats for return alot better. Desert Rose is a lovely resort next to Hooters and MGM Grand. A short walk to the strip short cutting through car parks. Small problem but quickly resolved by Judy the manager and Thomas Cook rep. Room space great and comfortable, could live there. Breakfast a bit of a mess, the food is good and varied but not many places to sit and eat, it is best to get there early. Now I know why people bring trays and baking tins down from their rooms and fill them up and take them back simply not enough room to sit. Will return without a doubt in the near future. Cocos restaurant to the right of Duke Ellington, just past the motel 6 sign.

May 8 2009 	Great location and staff	I looked at many resorts through RCI for my visit to Vegas. Most had construction going on, were not in good locations, or had bad reviews. My first choice was the Desert Rose and I was thrilled when a room opened up. Our stay was great. The staff was very welcoming and helpful. There were nice robes for us to use and a continental breakfast every morning. The location was perfect just a block of the strip near the MGM and Tropicana - we walked to everything. The bathrooms were small, but there were just two of us so not an issue. I would definitely stay there again.

May 8 2009 	CAN'T THINK OF ONE BAD THING	It's not very often in this day and age you can say absolutely nothing bad about a hotel that you've just left, but I can! Eight women made a Las Vegas adventure for 3 nights and 4 days and we all had the trip of a lifetime! The hotel is a big expense when you get away and I can honestly say that Desert Rose compares to those top-named hotels that most people with families can't afford. We ALL felt comfortable, well taken care of, safe and assured that we got a heck of a deal for the money. The hotel is just two city blocks away from the strip. Continental breakfast is free with your stay and we managed to drag ourselves out of bed to make sure we didn't miss the array of cheeses, eggs, breads, juices and fruit each morning. We even managed to arrive during their Friday happy hour and had our first buzz on them! The pool was clean, the grounds were clean, and the room was clean and neat. Security was seen in the parking lot and we were constantly met with employees that offered smiles - from the guy in the suit (making sure everything was done correctly) to the room cleaning staff and those other dedicated folks with very repetitious jobs. Again, we're talking eight women... How many places out there could have satisfied ALL of us? Thank you Desert Rose... We will be back!

May 8 2009 	Review a bit late but felt guilty not sharing how good the resort is!!	We stayed at the Desert Rose in Nov 2008, the review is so late but I always intended to give a great review of this resort and better late than never!! We were in Vegas to get married. We arrived 4 days before family arrived and couldn't wait for them to see the place. All the staff were amazingly friendly especially the cleaners and the lady who serves the drinks at the Manager's Special nights. The room was lovely and spacious and we were lucky enough to have a view over looking the gardens. If you do decide to stay here always ask for one of these rooms!! The rooms were very very clean and kitchen full with everything you need even a dish washer. The laundry facilities on site were a great help as well. On the day of the wedding the staff were very good bringing up flowers etc... The walk to the strip takes minutes, I bet less time then walking from your room to the entrance in one of the bigger hotels, and we felt really safe even wandering back at 3am! And the comp breakfast was very welcome every morning. This resort honestly cannot do enough for its guests which is very welcome and I hope it may always continue like this. The only probs we had were problems with flush in toilet (that was sorted within the hour by maintenance) and the key cards wouldn't work a couple of times (again sorted out very quickly). I will end by thanking all the staff from the Manager to the cleaners to the security guards and reception staff you made a very special time for us fabulous, and anyone considering this resort just go ahead and book it, its fab!!!

May 7 2009 	Well pleased with all features of this resort... as billed	We read about 3 full pages of reviews before making reservation. All positive pretty much. Probably the strongest rating we have given any resort that we have reviewed.Suited us perfectly. Location is great to the strip and monorail. Great atmosphere. Nice little pool to relax by if you want to do that. We would recommend to anyone and will stay here again hopefully.

May 7 2009 	Quiet little Gem and best value for the money hands down!!!!	Our family of 4 stayed at the desert rose May 1-6th 2009. I found the Desert Rose to be an excellent value for the price. I loved how it was only a 5 min walk to the strip, located in a quiet area. The FREE continental breakfast was FABULOUS, alot of excellent choices to eat.......one less meal to have to worry about especially dealing with trying to feed hungry kids first thing in the morning. The staff was always very friendly and accomodating, eager to help and always took the time to say "hello" The hotel was remarkably well kept, and they spent alot of time keeping the grounds neat and tidy. The pool is not large, but perfect for the kids to cool off in. Its nice to walk back into the hotel and NOT see a slot machine after walking the strip and seeing them everywhere - it was great to get back to the peace and quiet of the Desert Rose.The only downside, and no fault of the hotel is the ocasional wafting odor off the street, and a quite a few moths flying around outside and down the halls.......it was just the time of the year........we would stay there again in a moment, and are already planning our next vacation. We recommend this hotel to our family and friends - best value for the money, HANDS DOWN!!!!
May 7 2009 	I would definitly stay here again	spacious room, very friendly staff, loved the social time in afternoon, very quiet, but still close to strip

May 7 2009 	Can't wait to go back!	Having stayed here last year for a convention, I chose to come back this year without hesitation. The renovations going on last year are pretty much complete and they've done a great job. I used to stay in one of the large four star hotels on the strip, until I discovered this place. It's a short and safe walk to the monorail station which quickly takes you right to the convention center, avoiding the overcrowded shuttles and parking problems they have up there. It's like coming home to your own comfy condo at the end of the day. My wife joins me here for a few days now, enjoying a workout or some reading on the private patio and time by the pool during the day. We walk to the strip in the evening to get our fill of noise and bright lights, after all this is Vegas! We always say this would be a great place to bring our 7 year old, there are always a few kids around, but for now we're happy to keep this little hideaway to ourselves. It's squeaky clean, comfortable and has everything we need. Unthinkably quiet, considering the airport is nearby and huge casino hotels are literally around the corner. Think about a competitive nightly rate with free wifi and parking and you realize what a great value this is. They even have a simple breakfast and some late afternoon snacks put out. Just got back and already planning for our return!

May 6 2009 	Great Place to Stay	On my way to an outdoor adventure, I stayed for one night at the Desert Rose Hotel, recommended by the group I was to meet up with. Because of time contraints I didn't have the chance to visit the inviting pool or Rec Room. The concierge helped me with my e-check in and printed out the boarding pass for me. I would definitely recommed the Desert Rose Resort.

May 6 2009 	brilliant place	what a great place to stay off strip. We have just returned from a 5 night stay at the desert rose. Apr 24 2009 	Desert Rose Good Value For The Money	We just returned from an 8 day stay at Desert Rose Resort. Good location just a short walk to the strip and monorail. Nice looking property, comfortable accomodations, priced right. We encountered a few problems.... over flowing toilet, jammed safe, malfunctioning air conditioner. All problems were corrected in an acceptable time frame with a call to the front desk. Free continental breakfast was only adequate. It consisted of bread, cereal, bagels, hard boiled eggs, lunch meat turkey, and beverages. Not enough seating on all days we went. Many of the guests bring pans and "load up" with massive quantities of food and bring it back to their rooms. Do yourself a favor and skip the breakfast. Coco's Restaurant is a quick walk away. The food there is absolutely delicious, the service exceptional, free refills on all beverages and great bfast menu. Personally I would definately skip the continental bfast at Desert Rose. All in all; if you are looking for a non casino property this is a good value for the money. Something to keep in mind before booking is maid service is only every 3 days. We did call several times to request clean towels and they were quickly brought to our room, no questions asked, but daily clean towels and maid service would have been nice. I would reccommend this property to anyone who wants a non casino property close to the strip. It is a 3 star accomodation; not alot of frills; but clean and basic. I will close by mentioning that on our last day at the Desert Rose we found one cockroach in the kitchen. Management apologized profusely and told us that is common in desert properties to see roaches. We were told exterminators come weekly. ;-D

Apr 20 2009 	Great for families and a good value	We just got back from 2 nights at the Desert Pearl. What a great value! If you want fancy landscaping and pool valets who spray Evian on you, go somewhere else. But stay at the Desert Peral if you want a 1BR condo that has everything you need. Full kitchen, king size bed, adequate pool with free pool towels, sofa-bed for the kids, FREE breakfast, evening reception and NO gambling. Other than the fact that it's next to the Hooters hotel -- it's very kid friendly. Some of the reviews indicate that the furnishings were old and dated but it looked like our room was recently updated. New utensils, new fridge, new easy-clean electric range and dishwasher. It even has measuring spoons so it's very well furnished. The beds were older so if you don't like the old style sofa-beds, you might want to skip this place. The walls were also thin so when someone showers or flushes, you can hear it. This condo is a step above the typical kitchenette room -- normally part of the Shell Vacations Club time-share so has nice touches. The staff was friendly and left voice mail with the daily weather report. Breakfast buffet was hectic and not enough tables/chairs so we just brought a pan from our room down and brought food back to eat. The breakfast included cold-cuts -- which was strange. We just assumed they provided it for us to use for packing a picnic lunch. Only one compliant. They were doing some landscaping and seemed like "natural" fertilizer was used. But the smell just lasted for a couple of hours and didn't bother us unless we were outside.

Oct 28 2009 	Great the business traveler	My wife and I booked this hotel because of the relatively high rating at tripadvisor. We visit Vegas twice a year for leisure and decided to give this "green" hotel a try. I can say that this hotel is best suited for some types of travelers, but not every type. It is new, clean, and modern in appearance. I have no complaints in regards to the quality of the hotel. Although our one bedroom was quite cramped. The "studio" gives you a more wide open feel.I would highly recommend it for the business traveler since it has every accommodation and facility to support the business man/woman. Wireless internet is free and they have free fax and printing services. Very nice free breakfast buffet before heading out to the meetings.I would also recommend this for a family traveling to Vegas for some specific event (wedding, convention,etc.). Because it has a full kitchen in every room, it will suit families with children to the tee. I would also recommend this hotel for the buddies on a golf trip. There are so many exceptional golf courses within minutes (Red Rock Arroyo, Bear's Best, Siena). Golf buddies don't need posh accommodations, just a place to relax after 36 holes. I would NOT recommend this hotel for the romantic getaway. Sorry to say that we couldn't find any redeeming "romantic" qualities about this hotel. It's modern appearance, makes it slightly cold. There are no restaurants in the hotel, you would need to take the 15 to 20 minute trip to the strip. But then, coming back to the element after dinner just doesn't give you that "romantic feeling". I would likely not return to this hotel unless I was on business, going golfing only, or with my kids. Romantic getaway with the wife, No way.

Oct 9 2009 	Environmental Consciousness and Healthy Living-- In Las Vegas?	Element is a different kind of hotel, but different in a good way. It's the first hotel I've stayed at that seems to give serious attention to environmental consciousness and healthy living. The execution is not perfect, but it's a great start.The hotel is easily accessible off of the freeway and has plenty of free parking. The lobby is comfortable and inviting (as opposed to ostentatious or intimidating). The front desk service is genuinely helpful. And there are nice amenities even there, too, like a service to print out your airline boarding passes.The rooms are spacious and thoughtfully designed. There's a fully equipped kitchen and a comfortable desk. The bathroom has a "rain shower" but no tub. if you like to collect the little bottles of bathroom amenities, you'll be disappointed; the bath is equipped with environmentally sensible soap and shampoo dispensers. The beds are VERY comfortable and the rooms are quiet, making for a good night's sleep.There is a complimentary breakfast and an afternoon snack served in the lobby. You can also sit in the small but pleasant garden behind the lobby and eat. There is also a small pantry just off the main lobby that sells snacks and light meal ingredients at very reasonable prices.The hotel's service orientation and standards are first rate; they show through in the housekeeping, engineering and food service departments, all of which gave me excellent attention.If you want the glitz and glamor and excitement of the Strip, this place is not for you. But if you want some peace and quiet in a very pleasant setting, it's difficult to find fault with this property.

Located in Summerlin on the northwest side of Las Vegas next to the red rock hills, hiking and 12 golf courses.WOW! Our room with a King Size Bed was a full 400 square feet. It featured: full kitchen with dark bamboo laminate, non-skid, non-scratch flooring, aqua-green/taupe horizontal glass tile backsplash, under cabinet lighting, quartz countertop, under-mount stainless sink, digital dishwasher and IKEA inspired MTF white cabs-(inside were very contemporary square plates and the new "stemless" bubble wine glasses..) toaster, full stainless steel fridge (and ice cubes) paper towels...and ORGANIC cleaning agents-Seventh Generation.Bath was a "WOW" also: large and super clean it featured, full wall glass shower doors + Landscape shower head + chrome handheld bar shower all set into a surround of combination brown/aqua/teal bamboo tile and and contemp square 'pool' bowl on glass counter. They provide thick white, WESTIN brand towels and a hair dryer. Bedding was all Westin - even featuring a double duvet system. If you like to sleep cold, you can turn up the AC and sleep under a lightweight TOG summer duvet, or toasty with the added heavyweight winter duvet on top. All sheets are organic cotton-and are for sale in the room's Westin catalog of soft furnishings inside the glass topped desk. Bed was large and very, very comfortable. Grandchild loved the L-shaped taupe tweed couch that faced the swiveling, HI-DEF TV. This is a great stay for the internet special of $103 per room per night. Pool was ok for lolling about-only 4 feet deep. We used the outdoor commercial sized, outdoor stainless grill and invited family over for dinner. They allow pets 40 lbs and under on the first floor.Quiet cement floor and wall construction with absolutely no noise between rooms or floors. Quiet and 30 minutes away from noisy Las Vegas gambling city centre. Price includes cooked breakfast of healthy foods: egg-white & tomato english muffin sandwiches (bacon added if you prefer)- strawberry & yoghurt smoothies- banana nut muffins and Danishes and great coffee!FINALLY..a Spa-like hotel that is affordable !!

Jun 21 2009 	We'd stay at Element any time any where. A great hotel experience.	Element is a new hotel concept from W Hotels and they got it all right. Well designed, comfortable modern rooms with everything you need right at hand. Internet access. Refrigerator and oven. Well thought out desk area. Fabulous beds. Great bathrooms with spa shower. Free parking. Free breakfast with style and fresh juices. Location is away from the noise and congestion of Las Vegas which is a good thing for us. Nice restaurants and shopping in Summerlin.We were so glad to find Element. The best new concept in hotels today. Only thing I would change is towels could be bigger and fluffier.

Apr 30 2009 	Best Extended Stay Concept	This is the best extended stay hotel chain I have stayed in yet. Hands down beats the competition. Problem is there arent that many around. Hotel is generally quiet on the week days and really busy with families on weekends. Try to get a room (with an even number?) that does not face the highway- some road noise seeps in. Not enough to keep you up at night but noticeable. Location: Easy access off of 215 on the West side of Las Vegas, this is not a place to stay if you want to walk the Las Vegas strip. There is a gas/convenience store across the street, an Albertsons grocery store 15 min walk and by car there is plenty of shopping and restaurants one and two miles away. Outside the hotel there are long stretches of wide side walks good for running/joggingStaff: Friendly and courteous. The staff appeared to like working here which translates. Facilities: Modern minimalist. Pictures on their website are accurate. The social area has a large screen TV and a Nintendo Wii. There are two desktop computers for personal use and a kiosk for airline check in. Exercise facility had duplicate machines. Amenities: DVD Player, Flat Panel TV, Full Kitchen Frig/Dishwasher/Stovetop- no oven, plenty of dishware/flatware/pots and pans. They even supply sea salt and pepper corn grinders. Breakfast bar was well maintained and usually had one or two unique main course items a day. Evening appetizers were different each night and interesting not the usual fare you might find at a concierge lounge. Neither was a grand experience but enough to satisfy.Security: Room has hotel safe. The outside was well lit at night. Newly built up area felt safe.

Mar 22 2009 	Pleasant alternative to the Strip!	The Element is a great place to stay when you want to avoid the congestion, noise, and expense of the Strip. My partner and I stayed one night on our way to Death Valley National Park, and we loved the cool, modern design of the Element. We had a one room suite that included complete kitchen facilities, sitting area, and complimentary wireless internet service. The bed was just short of Westin's Heavenly Bed in comfort, but the shower and bath facilities were great! The hotel's workout room is well equipped, bright, and clean. Our room faced the highway, and we wouldn't have known without looking out the window--sound proofing was excellent.The only drawback (as mentioned by another reviewer as well): Breakfast service is woefully inadequate. The idea is excellent, but the Sunday morning on which we ambled down to the lobby area we found an army of guests including several families waiting for THE SINGLE STAFF PERSON to bring more breakfast burritos to the breakfast "buffet." A dozen burritos would arrive...a dozen burritos would disappear in a flash leaving everyone else waiting for the next delivery. The other components of the buffet--pastries, bread, yogurt--had all disappeared a long time ago. We would have been better off going to a local grocery store and buying some breakfast items for preparation in our gorgeous kitchen! (The hotel has a small pantry where you can buy a limited selection of frozen foods, pasta, and tomato sauce. Apparently wine and beer will be coming soon, but there is no full bar as in the Aloft Hotels) Or, there are several upscale coffee houses and restaurants in nearby Summerlin shopping malls that provide morning food service.Breakfast (or lack of it) won't stop us from returning to the Element. It's a comfortable, relaxing and low-stress place to stay.

Mar 21 2009 	Nice modern hotel good value	We stayed here in March. Aug 5 2009 	Fantastic !	We rented a two room suite and stayed here over the weekend of 4th of July We arrived around 9.30 in the morning and seeing that we were exhausted(had lots of baggages as we were only stopping by Las Vegas for 3 days en route to Nevada before heading home to New Zealand), the staff checked us in straight away. Jul 15 2009 	Nice alternative to the Strip	We booked this hotel at the last minute and got a good deal (I believe) with a AAA rate of $107 for a King Suite with a balcony. Jul 13 2009 	Great value	Stayed a Friday night - cost around $100 including evening drinks and snacks and full breakfasts. Wow!Had a great room, lots of room and very comfortable beds etc.Pool looked great.A little far to walk to strip, but monorail close by.Nice people.

Feb 23 2009 	Perfect for what we wanted	We choose the Embassy Suites Convention Center, because we had our 11 year old with us this trip and did not feel as we would be able to take advantage of a casino. The balconies are about 12 feet by 30 feet with several chairs and lounges. (See Picture) We only made the managers reception one night. About the same as any other Embassy Suites. This one how ever does not give you a limited number of tickets for drinks like I have run into at other Embassys, so it is all you can drink. The free breakfast is very good and the quality at this one was above normal. The room is typical Embassy, but I think they had just been re-done. Everything looked new and fresh. The bathrooms were above average size. The lobby has a computer to print out your boarding passes, but it was down, so the clerk offered to print them for us. Nice touch on their part. We rented a car, and this hotel is very conveniently located to the strip, and makes a good starting for doing all the touristy stuff. We had no issues parking at any of the casinos and malls. Day trip to the dam and Green Valley was only about 2 hours total, and worth the trip to me, but my daughter was not impressed with driving that far to see a Brick Wall holding back water. She would have rather just shopped that day. Did the sign. They have a parking lot now. Guess enough people were killed running across the highway that they decided it would pay for a lot. Once you park, you pretty much get in line and the tourist etiquette takes over. You offer to take a picture of the person in front of you with their camera, and then you ask the people behind you to take one of you with your camera, and so on. Pretty much crammed all the tourist stuff we could into our trip for our daughters sake. Volcano, Fountains, Conservatory, Sirens, Lions, Dolphins, M&M World, Caesars Shops ect. We did see Cirque du Soleil KA at the MGM. I will put up another review of it, but we really liked it. I do have to add, that I thought the porn slappers did a very good job of pulling back when my wife and daughter went by. They did put them back out for me after they walked by, but hey, at least they have tact. Overall, we enjoyed our stay at the Embassy Suites and would not hesitate to recommend it to anyone else. Sep 12 2008 	Peaceful in Vegas	This Embassy Suites hotel was a peaceful and very pleasant refuge from the craziness that is Vegas. We're not big Vegas fans, which is why we chose a non gaming hotel. This Embassy Suites is very nicely decorated and kept. The pool was clean and in a very attractive setting. Happy hour was okay although they don't provide many drink choices for kids and they are not allowed to order for themselves. Breakfast was very good, nice selection. The location was a bit far from the strip however the hotel does have a shuttle service and we recomend you use it. The front desk advised us not to walk to the strip but we didn't listen, It was a big mistake, it was so hot and not a great area to be walking in. Our teenagers enjoyed having Hard Rock cafe across the street. College was not in session while we were there so I have no insight as to what effect that would have on your stay. All said we enjoyed this hotel very much and it was probably the best thing about our Vegas trip.

Aug 26 2008 	GREAT HOTEL BUT A BIT FAR OFF STRIP	The Embassy suites is a lovely place to stay, the rooms are huge, we went with my 15 year old daughter. There is a bedroom with 2 queen sized beds, then a living room with a pull out sofa bed, chair, TV, fridge, microwave and kitchen area.The breakfast was divine and is complimentary. It ranges from healthy fruit and yoghurt, cereals, bagel and muffins to eggs, sausages, bacon, waffles, pancakes....the list just goes on and on.We walked to the strip on the first night and it took us 25 minutes (brisk walking) to the middle of the strip. The temperature was 93 degrees at 8pm at night do it wasn't a pleasant walk. There is a shuttle that is literally 5 to 10 mins walk away that takes you to the strip but it costs $5 each for every trip so can become quite expensive, al so the station inside the hotels for the shuttle, takes you at least 20 mins from going in the hotel door to getting to the station to board the shuttle, you could have walked there by then. I love walking but with the heat and humidity it wasn't pleasant.If I go to vegas again I would probably stay somewhere ont he stip or a little closer to the strip.

Aug 25 2008	Great Place for Families	We stayed here for 2 nights at the beginning and 1 night at the end of our vacation to Zion, Bryce, Page, Sedona and Grand Canyon. Perfect place for our family of 6-kids enjoyed a swim and although pool is small and indoors they just wanted to cool off. Breakfast included was a bonus.Very helpful staff and clean through and through.Good choice for off of the strip.

Aug 3 2008 	Typical embassy	This was a typical Embassy Suites. Away from the Strip, this hotel offers a much more peaceful stay that is still within a couple blocks of the action. The stay got off to a bumpy start when the key card would not open the door - however, we went down to the desk and the problem was remedied easily. That was in fact our only complaint, because other than that the service was excellent and the room was spotless. The breakfast every morning is amazing, and I'm sure there are not many places that can rival the selection offered there, especially considering it is free. All in all, great experience and definitely a good alternative.

Jun 17 2008 	Very very average	Typical suites accomodation but service was very slow - took half an hour to get a TV remote and even longer for some simple room service.
